titleStmt.title: A letter concerning the souldiers and their orders about the commissioners sent from the Parliament, to treat with the Kings Majesty. And the souldiers resolutions, and intentions therin also a letter concerning the levying of 91 regiaments of horse and foot in Scotland. With a list of the Lords, and other collonels of the said regiaments. And the declaration of the Committee of Scotland.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 9KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal licence. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: A letter concerning the souldiers and their orders about the commissioners sent from the Parliament, to treat with the Kings Majesty. And the souldiers resolutions, and intentions therin also a letter concerning the levying of 91 regiaments of horse and foot in Scotland. With a list of the Lords, and other collonels of the said regiaments. And the declaration of the Committee of Scotland.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for R. Smithurst, neer Pye-corner,

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A LETTER Concerning The Souldiers and their Orders about the Commissioners sent from the Parliament, to Treat with the Kings Majesty.
AND THE Souldiers resolutions, and intentions therin
ALSO A Letter concerning the levying of 91 Regiaments of Horse and Foot in SCOTLAND.
WITH A List of the Lords, and other Collonels of the said Regiaments. And the DECLARATION of the Committee of Scotland.
London Printed for R. Smithurst, neer Pye-corner, 1648. Sept ye 18th

figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE
figure.figDesc: royal blazon surmounted by a crown and flanked by the English lion and Tudor rose on one side and the Scottish unicorn and thistle on the other

div.head: A LETTER From PORTSMOUTH
div.p:
THE King is very busie in advise with the Lords and the rest attending His Majesty; There seemes to be great hopes that the Treaty will produce good; His Majesty seeming (now) to be more willing to comply then ever; The Commissioners are expected here: And there is a guard appointed to see the Commissioners
safe arivall, and that al mutinies, or insurrections that may disturbe the Treaty be prevented, and that there may be a free passage, between the King, and the Commissioners, and the Parliament. The Army do acquiesse to the resolutions of the Parliament, and doe not at all interpose the Treaty, expecting, and hoping the performance of what is promised both by His Majesty and the Parliament, that is, to injoy an happy and long looked for peace, and enjoyment of the Subjects Liberties.

THe Committee of Estates are labouring to raise Forces for defence of their owne Kingdome as they pretend, and have chosen 91 Collonels of Horse and Foot for every shire, respectively; A List of which I have sent you. It is believed that upon Lieu. G. Crumwells comming to Barwicke, the Clergy and the Marquesse of Arguile, will prevaile with the Kingdome of Scotland, to answer what shall be expected, and deliver the treacherous and perfideous Revolters to justice.

list.head: A List of the Collonels of Horse and Foot, appointed in Scotland, for the severall Sheriffedomes and bounds thereof, for preserving of Peace, and keeping his Majesties Subjects in a dutifull obedience to the Laws, and publique Judicatories, and in a Christian unity among Themselves.
list.item:
4 Regiments for the Sheriffedom of Edenburgh.
Earl of Dalhonshie.
Lord Croustone.
Lord Balmerino,
Laird of Collintown.

5 Regiments for the Constablery of Hardingtoun, &c.
Earl of Lawderdaile,
Earl of Wintown,
Earl of Twedale.
Lord Humbie.
Laird of Waughtown.

2 Regiments for the Sheriffedom of Peeble.
Laird of Prestoun granist.
Laird of Dawick junior.

4 Regiaments for the Sheriffedome of Barwick.
Earl of Home.
Earl of Haddingtown.
Laird of Langtown,
Laird of Plandergast.

4 Regiam. for the Sheriffedome of Roxborough, &c.
Earl of Roxborough.
Earl of Buclench.
Earl of Lothian.
Sheriffe of Tivitdale.

2 Regiaments for Laneriek.
Earl of Lanerick.
Collonell Hamilton.

5 Regiaments for Dumfriez.
Earl of Nithisdale.
Earle of Dumfriez.
Laird of Kelhead.
Laird of Lag.
Laird of Mouswall,

7 Regiaments for the Sheriffedome of Fiffe, &c.
Earl of Crawford,
Earl of Roths,
Earl of Dunfartling.

Lord Belcaris.
Lord Elcho.

5 Regi. for the Sheriffedome of Forfer.
Earl of Buchane,
Viscount of Dudope,
Lord Spynie.
Lord Briechen,
Lord Loure.

7 Regia. for the Sheriffedome of Perth.
Earl of Athoill,
Earl of Tullibardine,
Earl of Perth.
Lord Couper.
Lord Cardrosse.
Laird of Inchmartene,
Laird of Balthayok.

3 Regia. for the Sheriffedom of Starling, &c.
Earle of Callender,
Laird of Clakmannaine junior.
Laird of Palmais

2 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Lithgow.
Lord Levingston
Lord Bargany.

3 Regiam. for the Sheriffedom of Argile.
Marquesse of Arguile
Laird of Glenurquhy, jun.
Laird of Kilbarnic

2 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Bute.
Sheriffe of Bute.
Col. John Hamilton.

3 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Wighton, &c.
Viscount of Kenmur
Lord Garleis.
Laird of Garthland

6 Regiam. for the Sheriffedom of Air, &c.
Earl Loudoun Chans.
Earle Glencairne
Earl Eglington
Earl Cassillis,
Lord Rosse

9 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Aberdeene, &c.
Earle of Arroll

Viscount of Frendraught
Lord Halgertoun
Master of Forbs
Laird of Philorth
Laird of Morphic
Col. Hen. Mauld
Col. George Keith

2 Regiaments for Orkney &c.
Earle of Mortan
Lord Dalkeith.

2 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Kaithnes
Laird of Morkill
Col. Fan. Sinclaire

4 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Innernes, &c.
Col. Mac Kenʒic
Sir James Fraseir
Laird of Kilrawich
Sheriffe of Cromarthic.

4 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Elgine, &c.
Earle of Murray
Sheriffe of Murrah
Laird of Innis

3 Reg. for the Sheriffedom of Sutherland, &c.

div.p: In all 91 Regiaments of Horse and Foot.
